newsitem.title: USA: NY Assembly extends LIPA/Lilco hearings.
newsitem.headline: NY Assembly extends LIPA/Lilco hearings.

text.p: The New York Assembly Committee on Energy will continue its hearings on the Long Island Power Authority's plan to issue $7.2 billion in public debt to purchase the Long Island Lighting Co next week.
The "last road show" hearings had been scheduled for Thursday, committee spokesman Paul Larrabee said Wednesday.
Now the schedule has been extended to permit LIPA Chairman Richard Kessel provide specific answers to modifications in the takeover proposal that have been suggested during the committee's hearings.

In a letter sent to Kessel Wednesday, the chairmen of the Assembly committees on Energy; Corporations, Authorities and Commissions; and Consumer Affairs and Protection asked him to appear at Thursday's hearings or "an alternative public hearing during the week of June 9 through June 13."
"I will attend" a hearing to be scheduled next week, Kessel told Reuters.

The letter said "there is serious skepticism by many Long Island residents and businesses regarding specific promises from LIPA/LILCO on rate relief," financial commitments by ratepayers, and the consequences to Long Island's economy.
It said public concern has centered on four major themes:
-- the extent to which rate reductions will be realized;
-- the extent LILCO shareholders and officers receive compensation beyond the perceived value of the assets at the expense of ratepayers;
-- the necessity of issuing nearly $7.6 billion of debt that residents and businesses of Nassau, Suffolk and Queens counties will be pay for 35 years; and
-- the necessity of maintaining LIPA/LILCO monopoly control while the rest of the state benefits from the price reductions of a competitive energy marketplace.

Among the proposed modifications to the proposal the letter asked Kessel to comment on were several triggered by the "net gain to LILCO stockholders of (about) $2.0 billion" to be proviuded by ratepayers under the contract.

Noting "the use of these funds in currently unrestricted by the agreement you negotiated," an attachment to the letter said "the lack of any qualifications appears unreasonable," adding "ratepayers effectively are paying a premium for LILCO assets to assure the LIPA takeover."
It sought Kessel's opinion on:
-- a condition that LILCO invests about $2.0 billion in the utility's service area.
-- conditioning the purchase of LILCO's Nine Mile Point 2
stake on a plan approved by state regulators to operate and eventually decomission the nuclear power plant,
-- discounting the book value of Nine Mile Point 2 to be more consistent with prior testimony of LIPA officials,
-- discounting the purchase price of the Shoreham regulatory asset, and
-- including LILCO's generation plants as part of the proposal in addition to the Shoreham regulatory asset and the transmission and distribution systems on Long Island.
Currently, the plan is for LILCO to retain the generation and merge with Brooklyn Union Gas Co.

Thursdays hearings will be held at Nassau Community College, begining at 1000 EDT/1400 GMT; and at the Knights of Columbus in the Rockaway Beach area of Queens, begining at 1900 EDT/2300 GMT. ((-- New York Newsdesk 212-859-1610.))
